AI-Powered Marketing in Sri Lanka: The Real Story

AI is slowly becoming a normal part of marketing in Sri Lanka. According to the latest Digital Outlook Sri Lanka report, more brands are now using chatbots, AI content tools and even predictive analytics to understand customers better. Small businesses use AI to reply faster on Instagram, while bigger brands use it to plan campaigns and predict what people will buy next.

But thereâ€™s one big challenge, authenticity. Many Sri Lankans can spot overly â€œAI-ishâ€ content and some donâ€™t like it. So brands need to mix AI efficiency with a real human voice.

A few businesses are doing it well: local boutiques using chatbots, home-food creators using AI for content and corporate brands using data to personalize offers. They keep the human touch while letting AI handle the heavy work.

AI wonâ€™t replace Sri Lankan marketing but itâ€™s already changing how we work, create and connect. The brands that win will be the ones that balance both: smart tech + honest storytelling.

Lately Iâ€™ve been getting a flood of connection requests and cold emails, many of them pitching AI tools for generating art, video, writing, or other creative content. If you reach out to me to sell generative AI for creative development, I am deleting that request or email.
What surprises me... is how often these senders clearly havenâ€™t taken the time to understand their audience, what I do, or what I stand for. Do a little background check..lol. My career has been built around human creativity, and the artists that we hire are the lifeblood of our game. I will never use generative AI to develop creative work, whether it is art, narrative, video, or anything else. Generative AI is built on unlicensed, uncompensated, unethical use of artistsâ€™ workâ€¦its stolen.
The way I think about it is simple. When I go to a restaurant, I want a chef who cooks by hand, someone who puts their expertise, training, and soul into the dish. That is where the artistry is. But let a robot wash the dishes, clean the workspace, or organize the tools. Automation has its place. Let the artist focus on their craft. 
But if we let AI become the chef, we lose the soul and the flavor. We lose the irreplaceable artistry that happens only when a human creates.
For me, that is non-negotiable.

Cryptocurrency Trading: AIâ€™s Role in Digital Asset Markets 
 The cryptocurrency market has evolved from a niche experiment to a global financial ecosystem driven by rapid innovation and constant volatility. As digital asset trading becomes increasingly competitive, tradersâ€”both retail and institutionalâ€”are turning to Artificial Intelligence (AI) to gain an analytical edge. AI is transforming how market data is processed, how strategies are built, and how risks are managed in the ever-changing crypto landscape.

Why AI Matters in Crypto Trading
Unlike traditional markets, crypto trades 24/7, generating vast amounts of real-time data. Prices can shift drastically within minutes due to sentiment shifts, regulatory news, whale movements, or social media trends. Human traders often struggle to keep up.
AI, however, can:
Analyze massive datasets in milliseconds
Detect hidden patterns and correlations
Execute decisions without emotional bias
Continuously learn and adapt from new information
This allows AI-driven systems to outperform manual strategies

Free users get 30 videos daily. Pro users get 100. Everyone pays $4 for more. OpenAI found the line between adoption and bankruptcy.

Sora's shift to paid credits marks a turning point for AI video generation.

The math was brutal. Unlimited free video creation became "completely unsustainable" as demand exploded.

Here's what changed:

â€¢ Free users: 30 daily videos, then $4 for 10 more
â€¢ Pro users: 100 daily videos, then same pricing
â€¢ Future limits may drop further

This isn't just about Sora. It's about the reality of scaling AI services.

Video generation eats computational resources. Unlike text or images, video requires massive GPU power and bandwidth.

The industry is watching. Other AI video platforms face the same economics.

Freemium models work until they don't. The challenge? Balance accessibility with sustainability.

OpenAI is also exploring licensing for copyrighted content. Smart move or legal minefield?

The democratization of AI creativity comes with a price tag. That's not necessarily bad.

Paid models fund better technology. They also create barriers for casual users.

What's your take? Should powerful AI tools remain free or embrace paid tiers?

$74.97 for "lifetime" AI that runs $540/year-sounds off. Then you see 4M credits and the math flips.

As someone fascinated by AI pricing evolution, 1minAI's approach caught my attention. They're bundling GPT-4o, Gemini 1.5 Pro, and Claude 3.5 Sonnet into one platform-no more subscription juggling.

The lifetime deal breaks down differently than expected:

â€¢ 4 million monthly credits included
â€¢ 1.1 million words or images generated
â€¢ 450k bonus credits for daily login
â€¢ Access to multiple AI models without switching platforms

For content creators, developers, and small teams, this consolidation makes sense. Instead of managing separate tools for writing, coding, and image generation, everything runs through one interface.

The credit system provides transparency that "unlimited" plans often hide behind throttling. You know exactly what you're getting.

The math works if you use AI tools regularly. Equivalent monthly cost hits around $6.25 over one year-way below what most people pay across multiple subscriptions.

Lifetime deals always carry service continuity risks. But for those of us building AI workflows, the consolidation value alone justifies the experiment.

The real test isn't the pricing model-it's whether unified access actually improves productivity over platform switching.

Evolution of Agentic AI C/O Amazon Quicksuite 
 Today, whatever is new quickly becomes old. We started with AI, then moved to Generative AI, and now itâ€™s Agentic AI. Honestly, the lines blur because everything overlaps and shines depending on our use cases and requirements.
Before diving deeper, itâ€™s also key to clarify the difference between Generative AI and Agentic AI. 
Generative AI is reactive; it creates contentâ€”text, images, codeâ€”based on user prompts. It focuses on what to create when asked.


In contrast, Agentic AI is proactive and autonomous. It takes initiative, sets goals, plans multi-step workflows, makes decisions, adapts dynamically, and executes tasks with minimum supervision.


Generative AI powers content within these systems, but Agentic AI orchestrates entire processes to achieve goals efficiently, turning AI from a passive tool into an active partner driving outcomes.

Generative AI isnâ€™t just transforming content or analytics â€” itâ€™s reshaping cyber defense strategies. As cyber threats grow more complex, AI-driven models are stepping up to detect, predict, and respond in real time.

âš ï¸ Challenges:

AI is advancing rapidly, and two distinct paradigms are shaping the next era of intelligent systems: Generative AI and Agentic AI. 

ğŸ’¡ Generative AI (Gen AI)

ğŸ¤– Agentic AI

âœ¨ Together, these paradigms highlight the shift from AI as a tool to AI as a collaborator.

Digital health startups pulled in $3.5 billion across 107 deals in Q3 2025, and year-to-date funding has already exceeded $9.9 billion, surpassing full-year totals for 2024 at this stage. 

Why This Matters?

â€¢ Size + focus: The average deal size jumped, and mega-rounds (> $100 M) accelerated, signaling investor confidence in companies with scale and clear pathways. 
â€¢ AI continues to pull the bulk: AI-enabled healthtech startups captured ~62 % of VC dollars in H1 2025, showing where bets are concentrated. 
â€¢ Market maturity in play: While the volume of deals has softened, the size and strategic weight of each raise are rising. This suggests fewer but more impactful players are being backed. 

What Health-Tech Builders Should Take Away

â€¢ Itâ€™s no longer enough to just have a good idea. Investors are looking for scalability, defensible models (especially AI-driven), and strong go-to-market traction.
â€¢ If youâ€™re building in areas like ambient AI, clinical automation, data interoperability, the money is there, but competitive differentiation and execution matter even more.
â€¢ For vendors and providers: the funding surge means your partner ecosystem is getting stronger, expect more suppliers, more tools, more options. But also more noise.
â€¢ Strategic planning now needs to consider growth lighting, not just survival. Get your metrics, outcomes and product-market fit aligned with investor expectations.

Curious how your healthtech initiative stacks up? 

Whether youâ€™re building the next workflow automation layer, or positioning a clinical AI solution, happy to chat about what metrics and narratives investors are responding to this year.

Generative AI Is Changing How We Think About Customer Experience & Support
Modern expectations demand a new approach
The traditional support modelâ€”relying on scripts, long ticket queues, and static knowledge basesâ€”can't keep up with modern expectations. Customers today want quick answers, but they also want to feel understood. Generative AI is powerful because it has the potential to meet both needs, but only when it's applied thoughtfully.
When I started piloting these tools with my teams, I was especially cautious about how we used AI for things like call summaries or email replies. Those tasks seem simple, but they carry weight. One mistake can shift the entire tone of a customer relationship.
I remember a case where AI pulled a hypothetical example from a customer conversation and flagged it as a confirmed action item. The summary stated that a meeting with a major prospect had been scheduled, but in reality the client was just offering an example.
That kind of error could easily have led us down the wrong path if we hadn't reviewed the output carefully.
This is one of the most important things I stress with teams exploring generative AI: Always inspect what the technology delivers.
Fully 66% of employees rely on AI output without verifying its accuracy, according to a KPMG survey. Not verifying AI output can often lead to easily preventable mistakes. We still need human judgment. AI can surface insights and draft messages, but it doesn't understand nuance the way people do. We have to train it, monitor it, and stay involved.
When used well, though, AI can genuinely improve the experience for customers and teams alike.
I've seen AI-generated responses that reference past purchases, tailor product recommendations, and even adjust tone based on sentiment. These tools help deliver more personalized service without overwhelming agents. And that's key, because customers notice when a response feels specific to them instead of a copy-paste job.
AI also supports self-service in ways that couldn't be done before. Knowledge bases can be updated automatically based on frequent issues, which helps customers find answers on their own. That means fewer tickets, faster resolutions, and a more empowered customer experience.

QA Automation and AI Interviews: How Not to FAIL

More and more companies are introducing AI interviews as the first round of technical screenings for QA Automation and SDET roles.

The issue this causes is significant... your personality, your work stories, and all the details of the challenges you've solved don't matter in these interviews.

AI only cares about the right answer!
Interviews have become gigantic quizzes, where one wrong answer eliminates you from the pool. There's no human judgment or intuition here, just a binary pass/fail.

So what can you do? How do you beat this unfair game?

Well... by using AI as well!
You can use generative AI like ChatGPT or Claude to help practice interviews and come up with clever questions that AI might ask you during the screening.

BUT. There's a problem.

Generative AI is, well, generative, meaning it doesn't have any structure in the questions it generates. It doesn't have a complete understanding of ALL the topics that can come up in a QA interviews.

It doesn't understand the interconnected nature of QA.

And this isn't just a guess. This is constant feedback you can read on Reddit, LinkedIn, or X from hundreds of QAs who've tried using generative AI for interview prep.

So here's my question to you:

How did you solve this problem? Were you successful using ChatGPT or similar tools as interview prep? Did you try any specialized AI tools like QAmiAI (https://qamiai.com) ? How did it go?

Let's face it: most AI-generated sales emails are trash. They're just a faster way to send "hope you're well" messages that everyone ignores.

What if your AI acted like a high-performing SDR instead?

This week's experiment is a prompt that does exactly that. It forces the AI to:
- Interview you for context.
- Find a specific personalization angle.
- Write like a human, not a robot.

The full experiment and copy-paste prompt are in this weekâ€™s newsletter. Click the article link ğŸ‘‡ğŸ» to see how it works.

Everyone says generative AI will transform productivity, but the truth is far more uneven. Some firms are seeing impressive gains. Others are discovering that most pilot projects quietly fail. The real story sits in the gap between hype and genuine capability.

One of the most encouraging studies comes from Stanford and MIT. When customer service agents were given AI assistance, productivity rose by about 15 per cent. The biggest gains came from newer employees, who saw improvements of more than 30 per cent. The tools acted like an experienced colleague whispering advice over your shoulder. Over time, workers who used AI did not become dependent. They became more skilled. Customer satisfaction also improved.

Yet outside these controlled environments, the picture changes. A recent survey by MITâ€™s Project NANDA found that 95 per cent of private sector generative AI pilots are failing. Many firms tried to build outward facing systems for sales or marketing without the right data, governance or expertise. The successful ones focused on narrow and stable back office tasks with a higher tolerance for errors. They approached AI with discipline, not excitement.

The lesson is clear. Generative AI is powerful, but only when organisations redesign workflows, invest in people and start with the right problems. AI works best when it augments judgement rather than replaces it. It works best where errors can be managed rather than where accuracy must be absolute.

We need more realism and fewer grand declarations. Firms that approach AI as a long term capability will gain. Those that treat it as a shortcut will join the ninety five per cent.

The productivity revolution is possible, but it will not arrive through enthusiasm alone. It will arrive through careful design, patient learning and practical application.

Throughout my career, Iâ€™ve had the chance to experiment with Generative AI tools; however, I never looked at them as a way to replace creativity...

I've always looked at these tools as ways to amplify creativity.

AI, aside from writing faster, helps us marketers think differently. Think about this: you actually have tools at your fingertips that generates multiple ad variations, testing emotion and/or tone, in real time, backed by data. If you've been in the space as long as me (or longer), I'm sure the manual content creation days are still fresh in your mind.

Let's face it...this is not a Terminator-esque situation. AI isn't here to replace us...it needs direction. It needs a human touch. It can help us create great ad copy...multiple versions even...but not without our direction.

While AI gives us scale, humans give AI soul. That's where the real collaborative power lies.

Dynamic Competitive Landscape Forecasting via Adaptive Bayesian Network Fusion 
 1. Executive Summary


This paper introduces a novel framework, Adaptive Bayesian Network Fusion (ABNF), for dynamic competitive landscape forecasting. Unlike traditional static competitive analysis, ABNF utilizes a dynamically evolving Bayesian network to incorporate real-time data streams from diverse sources, enabling more accurate and responsive predictions of market shifts and competitor actions. The core innovation lies in the adaptive structure of the Bayesian network, which dynamically adjusts its variables, conditional dependencies, and prior probabilities based on observed data. This allows for a nuanced understanding of complex, multi-faceted competitive environments and facilitates proactive strategic decision-making. ABNF aims to provide a 25-35% improvement in forecast accuracy compared to prevailing methodologies, impacting strategic planning, resource allocation, and market entry decisions across a range of industries.
